title: Can your phone be hacked by a phone call? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, it is incredibly unlikely. First off, the entire “phone call” portion of a smartphone is very walled off from the phone’s main processor. This is to prevent people doing things with smartphones which disrupt the cellular network. It also eliminates exposure from some kind of potential exploit affecting the phone via a cellular call. So nothing is going to happen there. As far as using a SIP (or other application) on your phone instead of a cellular call, there is a potential exposure there. If someone found an exploit in a particular app and crafted a data stream to take advantage of this, I suppose something bad could happen. However, so far the worst that anyone has been able to do with cell phone exploits has been to crash the phone. As far as I know there has never been an exploit which resulted, even as part of a research project, in actual foreign machine code being given to a phone and have it executed. So the phone crashes? Big deal. So in order to “hack” your phone via a phone call someone would need to find an exploit and write a lot of code to (a) send machine code to your phone and have it executed, (b) create a data stream for this that could pass through multiple intermediaries to reach your phone, and (c) figure out how to send this data stream to your phone. Aside from this, just being able to execute foreign code on your phone is meaningless - what any self-respecting hacker would need to do is gain privileged access on the phone, which means another sort of exploit that provides privilege escalation. Once you are on the phone, this isn’t that hard to do as jailbreak and rooting apps show us. But all of this has to happen together. Not saying it is impossible, but it is very difficult and so far nobody has ever done it. So far, nobody has even come up with something you send to a current phone which crashes it. The last exploit like this was around 2012 I believe. So is there anything to worry about? If you are using regular cellular calling, no, nothing at all. Not even for the very paranoid. If you are using a different sort of Internet calling program, is there much to worry about? No. We are talking about a hurdle that is nearly impossible to overcome right now.

Strange that you asked me this question, in less than a week after a malicious malware attack was done to numerous mobile phones. However, as far as I am aware this has not happened on the cellular level, it could possibly be done but you would an excellent knowledge of how mobiles work. To be honest, it is not that difficult to develop a mobile phone these days, the parts are all available on places like Amazon or eBay. It is simple to develop an Android OS phone, using one of the latest mini-computers that is Linux based. The latest attack on WhatsApp can infect any mobile without you even answering the call. I wrote a post on this just a few days which explains more about it here:https://www.quora.com/Why-do-hackers-attack-WhatsApp-with-the-targeted-surveillance-attack-What-do-they-want-to-do-with-this-hack I would imagine cell phone hacking is pretty low at the moment because most hackers only know how to “reverse-engineer” code, not electronics (hardware). However, I only know about electronic “reverse-engineering” from decades of experience in the field, I started in the early ’70s when I was only 9 or 10 years old. There are professional hackers that do know software and hardware hacking, which makes this more dangerous. These you’ll find hacking cars, smart houses, refrigerators, right up to industrial level control of machines. I am not implying cellular phones cannot be hacked by just calling them, because nothing in the world is 100% safe, if it was we would not need security for our privacy, etc. So, as for your question, I would not state it was impossible. Never assume anything in this world today is secure, the more advanced techniques used in security just creates more security holes. One major company that falls into this category is Facebook, with 6 major breaches in the last 18 months! …and “no” I do not have an account!

Highly unlikely. Extremely highly unlikely. But possible I guess. As you have a data stream going into your phone, being processed, then output out the speaker, there is a possibility (albeit an extremely small one) that somehow your phone has a vulnerability in that process. They could then send specially crafted packets designed to exploit this, and somehow get access to your phone. Please note, this is nigh on impossible and probably never has/never will happen. Phone calls arnt a particularly viable attack vector, usually attackers look for places where code is being run based on input. In a phone call, the data is streamed to the speaker regardless of the data's actual content, meaning it's never really read. This significantly limits the ways this could go wrong. So yes, it's POSSIBLE, but don't get scared. It's ridiculously unlikely.

Apparently YES. Here’s a quote of part of WhatsApp exploit let attackers install government-grade spyware on phones – TechCrunch “The vulnerability (documented here) was discovered by the Facebook-owned WhatsApp in early May, the company confirmed to TechCrunch. It apparently leveraged a bug in the audio call feature of the app to allow the caller to allow the installation of spyware on the device being called, whether the call was answered or not.” (Emphasis added.) So this was found and fixed in WhatsApp. That doesn’t mean it isn’t present in some other app, or won’t be a bug in some other app in the future. Answering: “Can someone hack your phone by calling you?”

Yes. The hacker just needs to exploit the part of the phone that is easy to trick, vulnerable to all sorts of hacks and trivial to connect to remotely. You. By far the easiest way to hack your phone over voice would be to call you, claim to be someone in authority, like your bank or phone provider, then get you to install a malicious app, probably deliberately by passing the phones built-in security at the same time. Hacking the phone hardware using a audio call would be possible, but I’ve never heard of it being done. The worst similar item I’ve seen is making a phone crash by sending DTMF tones in a specific sequence, and that was on a phone last sold 15 years ago.

Is it possible that someone could hack my phone simply by calling me and I answer Hypothetically, yes. Some could spoof call you and Insert data packages into the stream of data. In reality, this would be very expensive and currently hard. Now, if you are on android and use any WiFi calling app, such as WhatsApp or Viber, this would be a lot easier to do. Lastly, this wouldn’t work on iPhone because of how data is stored.

As Jonas Kats said, hypothetically yes, but for the common man on the street the amount of effort and knowledge that would have to go in to such a project would be astronomical . Governments do have devices that can intercept your signal called a man in the middle attack and then they can intercept your calls, messages, photos you send etc. These devices are manufactured in Israel I believe but costs upwards og $500 000 . So it’s possible, but very unprobable
